journal-meta.journal-title: Journal for the Study of the New Testament

title-group.article-title: A Bio-Bibliographical Study of James Rendel Harris (1852–1941), Illustrated from his Discovery and Investigation of the ‘Absolutely Unique’ Logion after Matthew 17.26

abstract.p: James Rendel Harris showed a lifelong interest in the medieval MS of the Greek Gospels conventionally numbered 713 and particularly in Mt. 17.25-26. He argued that the saying attributed there to Jesus and addressed to Peter, ‘So you too give as a stranger to them’, was probably part of Tatian’s Diatessaron. Harris’s very considerable and rather arcane scholarship shows some unusual gaps.

sec.title: The Texts
sec.p:
At Mt. 17.25-6 Jesus asks Simon Peter,
τί σοι δοκεῖ, Σίμων; οἱ βασιλεῖς τῆς γῆς ἀπὸ τίνων λαμβάνουσιν τέλη ἢ κῆνσον; ἀπὸ τῶν υἱῶν αὐτῶν ἢ ἀπὸ τῶν ἀλλοτρίων; εἰπόντος δέ, ἀπὸ τῶν ἀλλοτρίων, ἔφη αὐτῷ ὁ ’Ιησοῦς, ἄρα γε ἐλεύθεροί εἰσιν οἱ υἱοί (NA27)
‘What do you think, Simon? From whom do kings of the earth take toll or tribute? From their sons or from strangers?’ And when he said, ‘From others,’ Jesus said to him, ‘Then the sons are free …’ (RSV, modified) (= version A below).

713, a medieval MS of the Greek Gospels, turns the last sentence into a question and reads,
ἄρα γε ἐλεύθεροί εἰσιν οἱ υἱοί; εφη, σιμων. ναὶ. λεγει ο ι[ησοὐ]ς· δοσ ουν και συ ωσ αλλοτριοσ αυτων.
‘So are the sons free?’ Simon said, ‘Yes.’ Jesus says, ‘So you too give as a stranger to them’ (= version B below).

sec.title: Harris in his Social Context
sec.p: 7131 has been in the public domain for 135 years, and its late-Victorian reception throws light on the cultural tastes of the times. In the nineteenth century it was not unusual for commoners in the United Kingdom to own New Testament MSS. In addition to the ancient universities, public libraries like the British Museum and the private collections of Robert Curzon (Baron Zouche) and Angela Georgina Burdett (Baroness Burdett-Coutts), MSS were to be found in the libraries of clergymen and scholars like Bishops Christopher and John Wordsworth (479), Henry Barclay Swete (709 718) and of laymen like the art critic John Ruskin (717 l[ectionary]238) and Quakers like the Braithwaites, the Peckovers (see below) and James Rendel Harris (P14 561/713 l1534). Harris was in good company.

North of the border, similar interests were evident not only in Alexander William Crawford Lindsay (Earl of Crawford and Balcarres) and the famous Bibliotheca Lindesiana, but also in commoners like Margaret Gibson and Agnes Lewis. In 1892 these indomitable twins, staunch Presbyterians, wealthy widows, self-taught scholars now living in Cambridge, at the age of 49 travelled to St Catherine’s monastery in Sinai, where Mrs Lewis discovered a palimpsest MS of the Gospels in Syriac.2 A return visit the following year (altogether six visits in 14 years), this time accompanied by Cambridge syrologues R.L. Bensly, F.C. Burkitt and Harris, elaborated this identification. The sisters would always enjoy Harris’s support; after Bensly’s death, in 1894 he joined Burkitt in publishing the first edition of the palimpsest, with the introduction written by Mrs Lewis.

The Braithwaites of London and Banbury and the Peckovers of Wisbech were scholarly families personally known to Harris. One would not immediately think there was a close connection between the Religious Society of Friends and MSS and the minefield of textual criticism. This assumption, however, would be mistaken; as examples of openness to new learning, as far as I know Harris was not even the first English Quaker to show an active interest in MSS and text.3 Excluded from the older universities, Quaker men often entered more recent foundations and then the law and banking. Joseph Bevan Braithwaite (1818–1905) was a London Quaker minister, ‘the Quaker Bishop of Westminster’, and a conveyancing barrister. According to Judge Sir Edward Fry, who had been a pupil in his chambers, Braithwaite ‘was a very dry lawyer, who loved … even the ghost of dead questions, with a warm affection’ (ODNB: VII, 298-300)—clearly Sir Edward was not a text critic! Perhaps after visits to Eastern Europe on behalf of the British and Foreign Bible Society in 1872 and 1883–84 Braithwaite had acquired 236 531 573 from Athens in the 1880s. A note on his bookplate pasted to its inner front cover says 531 ‘cost JJB [sic] ab[ou]t £5’ (an unbelievably small sum). Y (034) was procured from Macedonia in 1900.

His son William Charles (1862–1922) was also a conveyancing barrister and banker in Banbury. Sharing his father’s MSS interests, he found time to lead summer schools and reading circles on textual criticism. He soon collated his father’s MSS and published an article on 236, and two descriptions of Y of which a professional might be proud.4 The present writer owns the first two volumes of William Charles’s copy of Tischendorf’s Novum Testamentum Graece. He entered into the margin and apparatus of the first volume readings from both his father’s MSS and his own (479 2108=2640 l1259 l1982), along with those of fams1 13 713 TA at Mt. 17.26, the latter probably at the insistence of Harris (see below). As well as Tischendorf, these marginalia show his familiarity with the textual work of such men as J.W. Burgon, Scrivener, B.F. Westcott, F.J.A. Hort, Eb. Nestle, Gregory, Burkitt, K. Lake and H.C. Hoskier; sometimes he used von Soden’s new sigla. No name that should be there is missing. In addition, Braithwaite had had made an office stamp embossed with an א to signify not Tischendorf’s Codex Sinaiticus but the sisters’ Codex Syriacus Sinaiticus; he collated the palimpsest against Tischendorf’s text and apparatus, which he then stamped at the places where it had something to say. Though, as a Quaker like Harris, he had little time for the sacramental life of the church in a narrow sense, the liturgical details in the margins and text of the Braithwaite MSS received the closest attention. Y is now in Cambridge University Library, 2108=2640 is in Lincoln College, Oxford and the others are in Birmingham University Library.

The Peckovers also were bankers. An early name for one of their homes in Wisbech was Bank House, and its library, largely the creation of Alexander (1830–1919), banker, bibliophile and later Baron Peckover of Wisbech, was called by Dennis Bell ‘the repository for one of the largest private literary collections ever assembled in Britain’. In February 1876 his brother Jonathan (1835–1882) bought 712 for him at Quaritch’s the antiquarian bookseller; he bought 561/713 l345 for himself. On his death, 561/713 passed to their sister Algerina (1841–1927). She too was a book-collector; she owned a MS of the Life of Barlaam and Joasaph which she presented to King’s College, Cambridge in 1921. According to Burgon, 712 cost £200 and 561/713, which may have come from Athens, £50. In 1894, 1281=767 was added to the library for £200.

Unlike the Braithwaites, the Peckovers did very little with their MSS; it was probably Algerina who soon invited Burgon to examine 712 561/713. He published brief descriptions in the Supplement to The Guardian for 19 July 1882 (1001a). Burgon’s disciple Scrivener catalogued them, not without contradiction and error, in A Plain Introduction,5 and Gregory examined them in June 1883. But neither Burgon nor Gregory spotted the logion. As endpapers, 561/713 has 3 + 14 = 17 uncial palimpsest leaves, which contain references to lections from Romans and 1–2 Corinthians (= l586). J.N. Birdsall has listed what remains legible of these in JTS NS 35 (1984): 449-51. It is now in Birmingham University Library; 712 is in The University of California at Los Angeles; 1281=767 is in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.6

sec.title: Harris and 713
sec.p: After teaching for ten years in the United States, Harris returned to England in 1893 to lecture in palaeography at Cambridge (not ‘paleontology’ as in HTR 77 [1984]: 198!). In 1903 he withdrew his acceptance of or declined an invitation to or resigned a University Chair in Leiden, in order to become the first Director of the Woodbrooke Settlement in Selly Oak, Birmingham, now the Quaker Study Centre.7 Later he was curator of Eastern MSS in the John Rylands Library, Manchester, to return to Birmingham in 1925. He was forever working on newly recovered MSS, re-examining well-known ones and discovering new ones himself. As far as the New Testament is concerned, in addition to working on Algerina Peckover’s 561/713 and the sisters’ palimpsest, he continually busied himself with Codex Bezae (D), and between 1887 and 1900 published four studies of the the Ferrar-Group of MSS (13 69 124 346), now called fam13. In 1890 he edited a papyrus scrap (P14) that he had found in St Catherine’s, containing ten verses from 1 Corinthians.

‘By the grace of the owner’, Harris seems soon to have been given permanent access to, if not ownership of, 561/713 for his own leisurely study. In recognition of this kindness, Harris gave his patron’s name to the MS, but, if this is not too fanciful, in the sense that Codex Sinaiticus (א) is Tischendorf, though not so possessively 561/713 is Harris, so closely linked are the man and the MS.

Apart from A. Pott and T. Baarda only Harris has studied it thoroughly. He tackled 561/713 and the logion at least six times; J.K. Elliott’s bibliography lists the two most important studies.8 ‘Cod. Ev. 561. — Codex Algerinæ Peckover’ was published in December 1886; having collated 561/713 twice, in 1884 and 1886, Harris included in it a collation of Mt. 1–15 against Stephanus. Half a lifetime later there appeared in 1922 ‘The first Tatian reading in the Greek New Testament’, i.e. the logion at Mt. 17.26, a Greek sentence with a transmission also now found in Arabic and Armenian that strongly suggested to him links with the Diatessaron. The 1886 article, written with Harris’s customary good humour, moves from correcting Scrivener’s errors to a critical evaluation of recent work on the Calabrian or Sicilian origin of the Ferrar-Group recently proposed by J.P.P. Martin (Paris 1886) and then to a close study of 561/713. Only one page is devoted to the logion; it was ‘one of the most remarkable [passages] I have ever seen’ (Harris 1886b: 87), just as in ‘The first Tatian reading’, 122, it will be ‘a jewel of the first water’. It explains ‘a want of harmony between the question … and the conclusion’, requiring ‘the turning of the sentence … into a question’ (the MS clearly shows the question mark) which will require a reply from Peter and a response from Jesus. Harris also noted links with the Curetonian Syriac in the same verse as also elsewhere.

We can add four pieces to Elliott’s bibliography: two columns in the Philadelphia Sunday School Times for 6 November 1886, 707, entitled ‘An Important Uncollated Manuscript of the New Testament’, the two pages in Diatessaron of Tatian (1890a) and two minor pieces. The Sunday School Times piece shows that nearly two months before the December article which was intended for fellow-scholars, Harris had already introduced 561/713 to the American Sunday School world. Three quarters of it are taken up with still gently correcting the contradictions and errors found in Scrivener’s Plain Introduction (third edition) at 237; 175; 303; 666; they concern not only the MS itself but also its history at Bank House. In addition to 561/713’s ‘many peculiarities’ and ‘singularities’, the ‘absolutely unique’ reading at Mt. 17.26 was picked out. In Diatessaron of Tatian, Harris reported that TA now joined 713 in attesting the logion before the canonical form. Finally, he added to 713 TA TE/Arm’s reading of the logion alone (1893a: esp. 809-10); in 1927 he used the once-lost logion to parallel ‘A Lost Verse of St. John’s Gospel’ (1927: esp. 342-43).

After 1886 there were two important developments before the second major article in 1922: Harris changed his mind about the relevance of the Ferrar-Group and new materials came to light. As is well known, the Ferrar-Group re-positions the Agony in the Garden from Lk. 22.43-44 to follow Mt. 26.39 and adds ‘Isaiah’ before ‘the prophet’ at Mt. 13.35; in both cases 713 follows suit. The Group also re-positions the pericope adulterae from Jn 7.52 to follow Lk. 21.38; 713 also lacked the pericope after Jn 7.52 but did not have it at Lk. 21.38. But other links with the Group, especially with 13 itself, suggested to Harris that 561/713 did have a place there. However, as noted above, the 1886 article paid a lot of attention to the liturgical details in 561/713’s margins and text and from them Harris deduced that the home of an ancestor was Constantinople, not Sicily or Calabria, probably Sancta Sophia itself. This became part of the evidence, developed in the two later Ferrar-Group volumes (Harris 1893b; 1900), that led him to conclude that he had overestimated 561/713’s link with the Group, the origin of whose archetype was certainly south-Italian. He wrote, ‘We have not succeeded in throwing any fresh light on the relation between [561/713] and the Ferrar-Group. It is quite possible that the connexion is not so intimate as was imagined by me in an article published in [1886]’ (Harris 1893b: 17 n. 1); Harris 1900 did not mention 561/713 at all.

So, with the Ferrar-MSS out of the running, it was other materials that provided Harris with the clue to the logion’s affiliations. The recovery of 561/713, following Peckover’s purchase (1876), Burgon’s description (1882) and Gregory’s and Harris’s examinations (1883–1884), happily coincided with first editions of texts which soon helped to contextualize the logion.9 First was Ephraem’s commentary on the Diatessaron, in Armenian (TE/Arm), which, though published in 1836, remained inaccessible to those who, like Harris, did not read Armenian, until 1876 when G. Mösinger revised and published an old Latin translation. As we have noticed, 17 years later in 1893 he reported the presence of the logion in TE/Arm. But that interval was as nothing compared with the delay over unravelling Ephraem’s argument; it took Harris 35 (or even 46) years to get round to that in 1922! No wonder! It was ‘not easy to disentangle’ (Harris 1922: 125) nor ‘very lucid’ (126) (cf. ‘obscurity’, 127), nor was it helped by the fact that Harris had misread the (correct) Latin translation istum, which for typographic reasons had to be divided into i- at the end of one line and stum at the beginning of the next (Mösinger 1876: 162), as iustum, ‘that [man]’ as ‘just [man]’.10 This led him to see an anti-Marcionite tendency in the passage (something he was prone to do elsewhere) and to argue this at length (126-28); the implication that on his own showing Jesus was an ἀλλότριος (‘you also’) suggested a Marcionite gloss; or, it may be ‘a bit of true text’ (127) erased by ‘the Catholic party’ and its ‘zealous anti-Marcionite’ scruples about Jesus’ use for himself of what became one of Marcion’s titles for him.11 The second discovery was an Arabic rendering of the Diatessaron itself, edited by A. Ciasca (1888) (TA). Arabic Harris could read and, as we have seen, this time he did not delay in reporting that TA joined 561/713 in reading both the logion and the canonical form.

sec.title: Harris and his Colleagues
sec.p: But something of a shadow hangs over all this. While making full use of the newly available materials, in spite of his promise to summarize it (120), Harris’s 1922 paper did not refer to any ‘subsequent literature’ (apart from that of August Pott) published since 1886. S. Hemphill, J.H. Hill, J.H. Ropes, H.W. Hogg, Nestle, Burkitt, von Soden, A. Resch, Gregory, W. Bauer, A. Plummer and A.H. M’Neile had all been quick to incorporate the logion into their work,12 but Harris mentioned none of it. On the contrary he spoke about its being ‘overlooked’ (1922: 120), about ‘nearly forty years of quiescence’ (in correspondence at Woodbrooke).

The only ‘subsequent literature’ he does refer to is certainly the most weighty: the thesis of Pott (1870–1926), a German army chaplain and presently a member of von Soden’s team which was scouring Europe and the Middle East for new materials for the new edition. His collation of ε351/713 was forwarded to von Soden who classified it in the I Φ group, subgroup Σ and added the logion to his apparatus criticus (whence it was adopted as 713 by Vogels, Erwin Nestle [from 1927], Merk, Legg, Souter [second edition], Kilpatrick). When Pott published his thesis in 1912, he complained that von Soden had not grasped the implications of his collation and had used only what suited his theories; he preferred to class ε351/713 in the I J group, subgroup Σ (5).13

Harris acknowledged Pott’s interest in 561/713 (Harris 1922: 122), but he seems to cut corners. His account reads as though it were Harris who had initiated this interest by lending Pott one of his own collations. This overlooks the fact that Pott had already collated the MS twice, in 1897 and in 1904, and only then (‘endlich’) asked Harris for a loan of one of his collations, to clear up ‘Minutien’ (Pott 1912: 5). As we have seen, Harris asserted that the link with Tatian ‘seems to have been overlooked’, but, in addition to the scholars mentioned above, Pott’s thesis, of which Harris possessed a copy, is a detailed study of its Greek-Syriac-Tatianic text in Matthew. Pott has a valuable section on the temple tax episode which he regarded as fundamental to his thesis (1912: 6, 8-12); in it he distinguished the interpretations the pericope has without and then with the logion, and had anticipated Harris’s guess (‘it may be a bit of true text’), declaring that ‘die Geschichtlichkeit ihrer Substanz’ could be accepted ‘on other grounds’ but text-critically the logion is ‘vielleicht nur wahrscheinlich’ (1912: 11 n. 1). Pott also suggested that Harris had been hasty in finally dismissing the Ferrar-Group. Though Harris had spoken optimistically of ‘Dr. Pott’s assistance’ for future work on 561/713’s ‘Tatianisms’ (1922: 128), this was not to be; Pott died four years later, and in any case it is not easy to see how Harris would have substantially modifed Pott’s careful, though not faultless, work. If Harris’s partial collation of Mt. 1–15 (1886b: esp. 88-89) alongside Pott’s full collation of the whole Gospel (1912: 44-52) and the confusion of i-stum with iustum are anything to go by, perhaps not much.

In addition, while Wettstein, Griesbach, Tischendorf and Hill (1894: 249 n. 20) had already recorded a marginal scholium in 72 which quoted Mt. 27.49 combined with a form of Jn 21.34 and explicitly associated by the scholiast with Tatian, by 1922 Harris had clearly forgotten that that is ‘The first Tatian reading in the Greek New Testament’. Memory can play cruel tricks on an old man, especially with poor eyesight; though ‘im Silberhaar jungen Herzens’ (Deissmann in Amicitiæ Corolla, xii), Harris may have misjudged his physical and mental powers.

sec.title: Harris after 1922
sec.p: Prior to 1922 the logion was often noticed; since then the commentaries of Klostermann (1927), Gnilka (1988), Davies-Allison (1991), Hagner (1995) and Nolland (2005) and the studies mentioned in nn. 8, 13, 16, 19 and Plooij (below) have called attention to it. As for new evidence, the post-Great War era saw the publication of new materials for the Diatessaron, including mediaeval versions in Dutch, English, Italian, Latin and Persian, but the logion itself did not come to light. This silence persisted. Harris continued to work on the new evidence; in 1924 he wrote companion pieces on newcomers to Latin Diatessaron-studies. He was a close friend of Daniël Plooij, and as he wrote a preface to Plooij’s A Primitive Text of the Diatessaron (Leyden, 1923), one can guess the source of the reference to the logion in the apparatus criticus to the Dutch Liège Diatessaron which Plooij and colleagues later edited (Plooij et al. 1929–1971).14 Since 1922 the long-known TA has been re-edited and re-translated by E. Preuschen and A. Marmardji, and TE/Arm by L. Leloir. The Syriac original of TE/Arm has been recovered, also to be edited by Leloir (TE/Syr-Arm); this is easily the most important discovery since 1922. But no evidence has been forthcoming to disturb the conclusion that the logion is attested only in ‘eastern’ texts (713 TA TE/Syr-Arm).15

This brings us to W.L. Petersen and his criteria for recognizing a saying to be Diatessaronic: the first is that the ‘reading should be found in both eastern and western branches of the Diatessaronic tradition’.16 He does not regard the criteria as always binding but defends their rigorous application, since he would accept that ‘it does not always need a harmony to make a scribe harmonize’ (Williams 1942: 37; 1951: 1, 21). On the other hand, general considerations strengthen the link of the logion with the Diatessaron, even though presently attested only by 713 TA TE/Syr-Arm. (1) Since no Syriac nor Arabic biblical MS reads the logion, TE/Syr-Arm and TA, both derived from Syriac, presuppose a Syriac Diatessaron. (2) Southern Italy was ‘western’ only geographically; culturally it was Greek as the Basilian monastery of Grottaferrata near Rome shows. (3) It is widely, though not universally, assumed that Tatian wove a ‘Jewish-Christian’ source into his Diatessaron; for example, both ‘Jewish-Christian’ and Diatessaronic sources attest the great light or flame at the baptism of Jesus (Mt. 3.15).17 ‘Jewish-Christians’ would also have been happy with the sentiment expressed in the logion: even though they too were υἱοί́, like Peter they had been and wished to remain Torah-observant; my point is (B) may be flotsam washed up into the Diatessaron from the hulk of one or other of the so-called ‘Jewish Christian’ Gospels. Similar flotsam in the transmission of the same Gospel may point in the same direction.18 (4) In addition to Harris and Pott, the desirability of having western as well as eastern support has not deterred experts writing after Petersen’s 1983 article, like Baarda (1988a) and Joosse (1999), from regarding the logion as a Tatianism.

sec.title: Harris’s Jewel
sec.p: I conclude with a brief study of the ‘jewel of the first water’, which beguiled Harris for nearly 40 years. The final words of the canonical pericope read only δὸς αὐτοῖς ἀντὶ ἐμοῦ καὶ σοῦ (=A). 713 reads δος ουν και συ ως αλλοτριος αυτων (=B). TA TE/Syr-Arm read translations of (B). TE/Syr-Arm reads only (B) but TA like 713 retains (A) alongside (B) but with (B) first and (A) following in its usual final position.

We saw that Harris remedied (A)’s ‘want of harmony’ between Jesus’s question-and-conclusion (vv. 25-26) and the command in v. 27 by suggesting that (A) was replaced by the more coherent (B), to explain why Jesus thought that a question originally directed at Peter about only Jesus’ payment or non-payment of tax cannot exclude Peter. On the other hand, whatever their reasons, he and Pott were at least prepared to see in (B) not only a remedy and a Tatianism, but also ‘a bit of true text’. But replacing a puzzling (A) with (B), however harmonious, makes (B) the easier reading and provokes the question, would a scribe correct the harmonious (B) in favour of the difficult (A)? There seems to be no case for (A) replacing an original (B).

If, then, for argument’s sake (A) is the original, let us turn to the details of (B)’s remodelling of (A). After (A)’s δος αυτοις was remodelled to (B)’s δος ουν, two much more significant morphs were made: αντι εμου και σου, remodelled to ουν και συ, omits a reference to Jesus in favour of Peter, and with a change of number and meaning ἀλλοτρίοι, appropriated from vv. 25-26, is referred to Peter. Though (A) is retained in 713 TA alongside (B) and this may confuse the effect intended by (B), to exclude Jesus and move the spotlight on to Peter, could Tatian himself have had a second agenda, to introduce (B) early in the verse to signal how one should understand (A) later?19

The answer to the alternatives which Jesus puts to Peter about the payers of tax is all too clear. The sons of the kings of the earth or, in English parlance, ‘the royals’, are exempt from taxation, and it is the ἀλλοτρίοι who are obliged to pay. But, whatever they are, they are not foreigners (its usual meaning). Presented as properly liable to the fiscal demands of the government, they resemble ‘resident aliens’; so, in context the ἀλλοτρίοι are ‘non-royals’, and the alternatives are ‘royals’ who do not pay tax and ‘non-royals’ who should and do. Though the meaning of ἀλλοτρίοι in the canonical text was unusual,20 Tatian chose to retain it and reallocate its normal meaning to Peter alone. As an ἀλλότριος, he is a member of secular society and bound by obligations to it; as a υἱός he is also free from them (cf. 1 Pet. 2.11-17). To be ὁ πρῶτος τῶν μαθητῶν, the Senior Disciple, as Clement of Alexandria will put it (Quis div. 21), b(r)ought no exemptions.

The early church reacted in various ways to different elements of (A) and (B). I cannot find a parallel for (B)’s ἀλλότριος used of Peter alone. In the Coptic Apocalypse of Peter col. 83, ll. 16-18 he is commanded to ‘[share revelation with] the ἀλλογενεῖς who are not from this αἰών’, a positive command which Havelaar contrasts with the prohibition at col. 73, ll. 17-18, ‘do not tell … the children of this aeon (αἰών) …’ Both commands seem to assume that Peter too is ἀλλογενής,21 and represent a maximizing of Peter. Other allusions to Mt. 17.26-27 were concerned with (A)’s δὸς … ἀντὶ ἐμοῦ, which is partially ‘improved’ to (B); ‘partially’ because though δός is retained, some Fathers edited out (A) Peter’s paying for Jesus and then somehow deduced it was Jesus who paid. The need to re-evaluate Peter was not concerned that (A) and (B) give no grounds for that particular deduction. Clement of Alexandria interpolated ‘alone’, and especially Jesus’ paying, to justify his extravagant encomium of Peter, ὁ πρῶτος τῶν μαθητῶν, ‘for whom alone (ὑπὲρ οὗ μόνου) and himself the Saviour paid tribute’. Ambrosiaster recalls a critic who had acutely asked, ‘Since all had left everything and followed him, why did the Saviour pay a double drachma for himself alone (tantum) and for Peter and not for the other apostles?’ Clement’s μόνου resembles Ambrosiaster’s tantum; so if, as P. Courcelle argued, it is Porphyry against whom Ambrosiaster is reacting, one Neo-Platonist is found mocking another. Acts of Thomas 143 is much briefer: it was Jesus who paid ‘at the end for himself and for his disciples’. In short, Jesus pays for all the disciples, Peter is deposed. Epistula Apostolorum 5 takes the last point further: it was the disciples (as a body) who paid the tax ‘for me and for you (plural)’.22

Harris’s discovery and investigation of (B) provide more evidence for the early church’s remodelling of (A); it shows that Peter was both maximized, by the addition of ἀλλότριος and ‘alone’, and minimized, by the Senior Disciple’s no longer acting on behalf of Jesus and the other disciples. Peter’s Primacy in the second century was far from settled.23

fn.p: 713, the siglum in current use, was first used by C.R. Gregory (1884–1894). Other sigla for this MS have been 561 (the only siglum Harris ever used), first in Scrivener (1883, 3rd edn); ε 351, first in von Soden (1902–1913); for historical reasons Birmingham University Library retains two other sigla for 713: Codex Algerinae Peckover 561 and Mingana-Peckover Greek 7, not to be confused with Mingana Greek 7, a musical MS. 713 is described by Pott (1912: 6-8) and Hunt (1997: 42-58, passim) from an art-historical and codicological perspective; apparently the scribe of 713 was left-handed (Hunt 1997: 44, 50 and n. 30). Unless the reference is to dates or pages, other numbers, like 713, refer to the MSS and lectionaries (l) recorded in Aland (1994). MS numbers in a series are separated by a double space. All italics in reported speech are my own.

Harris posted news of the discovery of the palimpsest in the Academy 42: 110 and Athenæum: 196, both for 6 August 1892 and discussed it at length in the Contemporary Review LXVI, November 1894: 654-73. Meanwhile Mrs Lewis amplified the news in the Academy 43: 326, an abbreviated form appearing in the Athenæum: 475, both for 15 April 1893. See the biographies of the sisters by Cornick and Binfield (2006) and Soskice (2009). They went on to edit all manner of Christian-Syriac and Christian-Arabic treasures, sometimes collaborating with another of Harris’s friends, the emigré-scholar Alphonse Mingana (1878?–1937). He edited seven volumes of Woodbrooke Studies (1927–1934) and two of the six volumes of Catalogue (1933–1963); see Hunt 1997.

Samuel Fisher (c. 1604–1665) was an Anglican-turned-Quaker controversialist, a visitor to Holland where he made the acquaintance of Spinoza. He used the textual uncertainties of the biblical text to promote the sole authority of the Inner Light; see Hill 1975; Popkin 1985; Hessayon and Keene 2006; Frampton 2006. In his evaluation, Cadbury cited John Faldo who called Fisher ‘the best scholar that ever professed Quakerism’ (1947: esp. 183-88). Tregelles (1813–1875) was brought up amongst Quakers, but this eminent text critic did not adopt distinctly Quaker principles for himself; the Preface to An Account (1854), shows something of his decisive views about Scripture. See Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (ODNB): XIX, 717-18 (on Fisher); LV, 266-67 (on Tregelles).

Braithwaite 1890, 1901–1902, 1904. Gregory (1900–1909: III, 1027-37) borrowed extracts from Braithwaite’s description and collation of Y, warmly acknowledging both them and information about l1259. Braithwaite was also a gifted amateur historian; he had found time to write two books on the history of early Quakerism, 1,300 pages in all, for which the University of Marburg conferred on him an honorary doctorate a few weeks before his death. Thomas and Emmott wrote biographies of their father and brother (1909: esp. 335-37; 1931: esp. 19-20); on the latter, see The Friend NS 62 (1922): 26, 71-73, 97-100, 753-54. On Peckover and the Braithwaites as professional men, see Milligan 2007: 64-65, 332-33. For Alexander Peckover’s library, see Rann 1910: esp. 515-16.

As one of Britain’s leading New Testament textual critics since the 1850s, an overview of the reception of Scrivener’s four editions (1861, 1874, 1883, 1894) further helps to put Harris in his academic context. Two unsigned reviews had welcomed the first edition, one in The Christian Remembrancer 43.116 (1862): 385-421, the other in the London Quarterly Review XX/40 (1863): 542-46. The former was a long, learned and typically Burgonesque review with ‘F.J.A.H[ort]’ already in the firing line (pp. 399-401, 408-409, 416)! O. von Gebhardt reviewed the second edition at length in TLZ 1 (1876), cols. 129-34. Though H. Wace’s review of the third edition in the Contemporary Review 44 (1883): 460-64 agreed with the attacks on Westcott and Hort, scholarly opinion was changing. In The American Journal of Philology 5 (1884): 96-99 Harris referred to the ‘multitudinous errors’ in the earlier editions repeated in the third; in 1885 he had joined American colleagues in listing them (Thayer 1885). The sad story continued in the Sunday School Times (1886) (see below). Edward Miller, the editor of the new fourth edition (1894: see I, vii), cited Scrivener’s overwork and illness as reasons. This edition fared no better: though not unsympathetic, the anonymous reviewer in The Guardian for 30 May 1894: 820-21, was scathing: the first volume was ‘seriously untrustworthy’ and the ‘American corrections’ and Gregory’s Prolegomena had been largely neglected. Again Miller responded; letters to the Academy for 22 September 1894: 217 and 15 December 1894: 514 pleaded illness, limited time and limited access to the ‘American Notes’. Though not blind to their errors, Gregory was much gentler about the third (Academy for 26 January 1884: 57-58) and fourth editions (Academy for 29 December 1894: 559). The Classical Quarterly 10 (1896): 263-65 and The Church Quarterly Review 39.77 (1894): 151-59 were politely critical. As the latter noticed (39.78 [1895]: 558-59), later issues of the fourth edition inserted ‘additional information and some corrections’ at I, 391*-98*; II, 417*-18*. Their colleagues were embarrassed by Scrivener’s and Miller’s lack of rigour; Scrivener’s condescending manner towards opponents and assistance offered from across the Atlantic did not help. The fact that two Americans (Ezra Abbot and esp. Gregory) had just completed the massively splendid Prolegomena (1,428 pages), now available for comparison, only made matters worse. J. Lionel North has discussed the later stages of this controversy and especially Miller in Taylor 1999: 1-25.

Rann (1910: esp. 517-18) enthusiastically describes two Greek MSS belonging to Alexander Peckover. One is certainly 712; the other may be 1281 = 767. For the manuscript-collections in Banbury, Birmingham and Wisbech, see Olivier 1995: esp. 136, 161, 506-507, 840-41; see also Hunt’s description (1997) of some of these MSS.

Did Harris withdraw or decline or resign? Cf. ‘HJdeJ[onge]’ in Falcetta 2003: esp. 299; Falcetta 2006: 6. Withdrawal is clearly implied by three men who were very close to Harris, viz. Lake (1906), Phillips (1941: esp. 349-50) and Wood (1953: esp. 58-59); Who was Who 1941–50, s.v. Wood (1933: 82) adds that Harris also declined a Chair at Mansfield College, Oxford.

Elliott 2000: 149; ‘Cod. Ev. 561.-Codex Algerinae Peckover’, JBL 6 (December, 1886): 79-89; ‘The First Tatian Reading in the Greek New Testament’, Expositor 8.23 (1922): 120-29; repr. in Falcetta 2006: ch. 6. Harris’s publications on the Diatessaron, the Ferrar-Group and P include: The Diatessaron of Tatian (DT), (1890a: esp. 43-44; 62-68 on W [= 0131] with two plates; 44-45 on Mt. 17.26 in 713 T; 45-51 on other Tatianisms in Greek); The Origin of the Leicester Codex of the New Testament (1887); On the Origin of the Ferrar-Group (1893b); Further Researches into the History of the Ferrar-Group (1900); Biblical Fragments from Mount Sinai (1890b: 54-56). Phillips spoke of ‘the famous Peckover reading’ in Wood 1933: 229. J. Delobel refers to the logion passim (1982: esp. 432-45). See Bernet 2009. Falcetta promises a biography.

An even happier coincidence soon followed. Shortly after Harris discovered a Syriac MS of the long-lost Apology of Aristides at St Catherine’s in Sinai in 1889, his friend J. Armitage Robinson discovered in Vienna a Latin version of what eventually proved to be much of its Greek original! In that way Harris’s edition of the Syriac could include Robinson’s Greek (and Armenian) texts (Harris: 1891/1893).

It was Ephraem’s Commentary which inspired Robinson to learn Armenian (Handes Amsorya 41 [1927]: 981), so it is strange that Robinson, who assisted Harris with the Armenian in ‘The first Tatian reading’, did not spot the mistake. Neither the Commentary nor the Harrises’ relief work among Armenian Christians in Ottoman Turkey in the 1890s inspired him to do likewise. In his (1897) review of J.H. Hill (1896), Harris regretted his ignorance of Armenian. Two years after ‘The first Tatian reading’, Harris published under his own name an introduction to and translation of an Armenian version of Tatian’s ‘Perfection according to the Saviour’; one sentence, ‘When we examine our Armenian text more closely we see …’, should be read in the light of another acknowledging ‘the help which Mr. [F. C.] Conybeare has given me in the translation of the Armenian text’ (1924a: esp. 21, 51). By contrast, in 1894 Ann Mary Burgess, another Quaker, learned both Armenian and Turkish to prepare herself for similar work; cf. Tusan 2009: esp. 633.
Cf. Chadwick 1953: esp. 368-69; Origen, Contra Celsum 6.52-53 (SC CXLVII, 308 n. 3).

Hemphill 1888: 78; Hill 1894: 142 n. 2, 302, 358; 1896: 14, 100; Ropes 1896: 112-13; Hogg 1897: 82; Nestle 1899: 73; Burkitt 1904: I, 98-101, II, 192, 274, but not in his ‘Appendix’ to the Westcott-Hort text (London 1896, 2nd edn: 14*, 143*); von Soden 1902–1913: I, 1229 (cf. 55, 177, 1220-26, 1229-30; II, 63); Resch 1906: 37-38; Gregory 1908: 25; Bauer 1909: 390-91; the commentaries of Plummer (1909) and M’Neile (1915) ad locc. Parallel with Harris in this regard is the great Diatessaronforscher T. Zahn, who showed no awareness of his contemporaries’ references to 713 and Mt. 17.26. Six years after Harris’s first article, Zahn was still using only Armenian (via Mösinger’s Latin) and Arabic materials (via Åkerblad’s, Rosenmüller’s and Ciasca’s Latin where available) (1892: I, 546), not advancing beyond the data he had used earlier (1881: 166). The fourth edition of his commentary on Matthew (1922) still did not refer to 713.

Pott 1912: 5, 36-41. Pott (1920) (reviewed in TLZ 46 [1921]: coll. 80-81) continued to criticize von Soden, also in his contribution to Preuschen 1926: 1-60, noticing 713 and the logion at 36 n. 2. He also collated 58, presumably for von Soden; cf. Nestle 1903: 190. The review of Pott’s thesis in TLZ 38 (1913): coll. 233-34 noticed errors in the collations, as did G.D. Kilpatrick, who claimed that it was von Soden who was responsible (1942: 31); see also Klijn 1949: 61-67, esp. 65-66 on the logion.

Goates 1922: 59; Todesco, Vaccari and Vattasso 1938: 85, 273; Messina 1951: 228-29; Harris 1924a: 349-62; 1924b 32-45; 1924c: 349-62; Plooij et al. 1929–1971: III, 284-85. I too have found no trace of the logion in any Latin witness.

Marmardji 1935: 240-41, also translated by Preuschen (1926: 142) and Leloir (1953: 196, ET 1954: 141; 1963: 128). Leloir’s two monographs (1961 and 1962) mention neither the logion nor 713. Leloir also translated the logion in T (1966: 253), as have McCarthy (1993: 221) and Lange (2008: 419).

Petersen 1983: esp. 490. U. Schmid also teaches the need to discriminate when he criticizes the tendency to see western corroboration in any non-Vulgate, especially vernacular, reading, wherever found and whatever its date (2003); similarly, Schmid with den Hollander 2007. Mention must be made of Petersen’s magnum opus (1994) and his summary of it (1995), but neither piece mentions the logion or Pott’s monograph. I am grateful to Professor T. Baarda for a copy of his article (1988a), lately come to hand. He draws attention to Harris’s misreading of the Latin translation of T (111-12) which had puzzled Birdsall, who asked, ‘How did this phrase come into Harris’s text?’ (1965: esp. 136). Neither Birdsall nor Baarda attempted an explanation of the misreading. Elsewhere Baarda (1999) has shown that Zahn and Plooij also were misled by their dependance on Mösinger’s Latin in Taylor (1999: esp. 171-73, 180). See Joosse 1999: 73 for Zahn’s ignorance of Arabic.

Epiphanius reports that some called the Diatessaron ‘the Gospel of the Hebrews’ (Panarion 46.1.9 in J. Dummer (ed.), Epiphanius II [2nd edn; GCS; Berlin, 1980]: 204-205). For the light or flame at the baptism, cf. Drijvers and Reinink 1988: 91-110; Birdsall 2009: esp. 534-37.

See 18.7; Hill 1894: 143 n. 1; Resch 1906: 106-107; its fuller, more balanced form is quoted by Clem. Hom. 12.29 (in F. Paschke [ed.], Pseudoklementinen I Homilien [2nd edn; GCS, 42, Berlin, 1969]: 189), by Aphrahat, Dem. 5.1 (in J. Parisot [ed.], Patrologia Syriaca 1/1 [Paris, 1894]: 184) and possibly by Ephraem; both used the Diatessaron; see also 19.17; its fuller form is very amply documented in Strecker 1958: 131. Are there parallels in ‘Jewish-Christian’ literature for non-Matthaean Tatianisms, for example Jesus’s looking at the rich man ‘with love’ (Mk 10.21); the Davidic descent of Mary (Lk. 1.17 etc.)? These four passages are not recorded in NA.

For Tatian as text critic, see Hill 1894: 292-317, who asterisked a hundred passages found in T but not in the Peshitta and Curetonian Syriac ‘as being probably due to Tatian himself’; Mt. 17.26 is included; C.S.C. Williams (1942: 37-42) lists thirty readings which show the influence of Tatian on Greek MSS; four of them from Matthew (2.8; 19.15; 21.20 as well as 17.26) are attested by 713; Williams 1951: esp. 23. For Ephraem as text critic, see Hill 1894: 16-17; 1896: 26-28; Hemmerdinger-Eliadou 1973: 313-93. She used Pott’s collations for 713’s text of Matthew (1973: 320-21, 338).

The rendering ‘others’, found in the Bible in Basic English, English Standard Version, God’s Word, NIV, NRSV, RSV, Twentieth Century and Weymouth translations, not only is inaccurate in itself, but also ignores Matthew’s context.

For ἀλλογενεῖς, see Havelaar 1999: col. 83, l. 17, p. 104. Its ‘political ecclesiology’ is summarized in Franzmann 1996: 169, 187-88. G. Luttikhuizen (2003: 197; col. 78, ll. 25-26; col. 83, ll. 17-18) links ‘children of light’ and ἀλλογενεῖς to describe Christ’s followers ‘in this world’. If the two words were linked in some way, this would be a neat parallel for Peter’s ambiguous existence in this world as both υἱός and ἀλλότριος. LXX translated יךבנ by both ἀλλογενής and ἀλλότριος.

Clement of Alexandria, Quis dives salvetur? 21 (in L. Früchtel and U. Treu [eds.], Clemens Alexandrinus III [2nd edn; GCS; Berlin, 1970]: 173); Ambrosiaster, Quaestiones Veteris et Novi Testamenti 79 (in A. Souter [ed.], CSEL l [Vienna, 1908]: 133); cf. Courcelle 1959: esp. 169, 148-49; EpAp 5 (in C. Schmidt [ed.], TU XLIII [Leipzig, 1919]: 31); ATh 143 (in Lipsius and Bonnet 1959: II/2, 250). I suggest this time-line: (A) → Tatian ap. (B) → EpAp → Clement → ATh → Porphyry ap. Ambrosiaster.
For the ‘later subordination of Peter under James’, see Cullmann 1953: 224-26; for ‘Anti-Peter Tendencies’–‘Pro-Peter Tendencies’, see Smith 1985.

ref-list.title: References
ref-list.p: (Nineteenth-century newspaper articles and similar publications are omitted.)
